fields.description:
Upload a file or create a directory with // in the path.
S3cmd tool show it correctly
{code}
[vasya@localhost ec2-tools]$ s3cmd -c s3cfg-qa ls s3://import/1741ec96-37f0-4d5e-a064-13c1cd182890//tmp/
2015-01-06 21:17      1579   s3://import/1741ec96-37f0-4d5e-a064-13c1cd182890//tmp/demo-test.img.manifest.xml
2015-01-06 21:17  10485760   s3://import/1741ec96-37f0-4d5e-a064-13c1cd182890//tmp/demo-test.img.part.0
{code}
but console shows empty folder without name and there is no way to drill down into it.
Console also can't delete this folder or its parent folder.
fields.summary: Console can't deal with directories that has // in the path

comments.body: [~jloza], let's figure out what to do here. We take the values between the / characters to be the folder name. In this case, that value is empty. We should do something, but I'm not clear what... we could simply ignore the empty part of the path and display the next value instead (so, in the example above, we could show "tmp" instead of the blank value). Perhaps another option is to use some kind of placeholder for the empty path value, or an icon.

[~dkavanagh], I would like to see how AWS console and Cyberduck handle these. Is it possible to use S3cmd to get into our AWS account and create a folder in there with // so we can see how these consoles do?

I've tested with the AWS console and it appears that if I have a key "blah//test", that I get a folder called "blah" with contents of "test". It seems to ignore the empty segment of the path (and simply collapse it).
The URL given for the object is : https://s3.amazonaws.com/euca-dak/blah/test so now I wonder if something isn't being done either in boto or S3 to remove the extra slash.
It appears that boto is removing the extra slash:
2015-01-08 13:15:17,434 euca [DEBUG]:StringToSign:
PUT
risfylFZSeXVT7IrjtlVdQ==
application/octet-stream
Thu, 08 Jan 2015 18:15:17 GMT
/euca-dak/dak/test

I'll have to try with s3cmd (ugh, now I need to get and configure that)
[~vasya], you'll have to help with that one. Sounds like an EC2 API call that creates an S3 object on your behalf. What tool did yo use to import? (euca2ools?)
[~dkavanagh], I've used euca-import-volume. There is a chance that this is the tools issue. At the same time I'd expect storage to reject // paths if this invalid.
Thanks, [~vasya], I'll mess with euca-import-volume. I see that other tools explicitly avoid this situation, so I'll have to see what's causing the issue with euca-import-volume.
[~dkavanagh], I am wondering if tools avoid this to prevent an error from S3. [~gholms], do you have any insights on that?
Consecutive / characters are perfectly valid in key names.
Let's do some due diligence on this one to recreate, but this seems like a corner case and should be pushed once that is done.

I've recreated the issue with this command:
euca-import-volume -I <access> -S <secret> -U http://ec2.us-west-1.amazonaws.com build//lib/S3/Utils.py -f raw -z us-west-1a -b euca-dak --s3-url http://s3.amazonaws.com

Notice, I just referenced a file relative to my current directory, but used a double slash which is valid in loading files locally. This tool passes that along to S3.
In the AWS console, this shows up as a directory with no name. I am allowed to click down into it, so that works. I find that their breadcrumbs don't accurately reflect the extra directory level, so that's a minor flaw.

In our console, we do show the empty directory name and a folder icon, but I'm not able to click down. I click the folder and the current directory is just reloaded and I can't get past. Manipulating the URL to force the extra slash doesn't seem to help either.

I'm sure we could fix this, but it's rather a corner case and could certainly be put off till later.
Yep, great to know, let's fix in a post-4.1 release. Thanks for investigating, [~dkavanagh]

This one is a little complicated. either pyramid or the WSGI server (probably the later) is parsing the subpath, which contains the key name. It splits the path into elements, removing the "/" characters. In this case, those are key (no pun intended). The actual path is still available in the request.environ, so I wrote a method to use that instead. It is just tricky to get that used for all the url path construction for XHR calls.
PR 1260 needs a few fixes and unit tests
updated the PR. Going to link a new issue we need to document for 4.1.1
Verified that // resolves by replicating test with euca-import-volume
